standard_metadata.standard_description: Compare two decimals to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

hints.content: Let's use a place value table to compare our two numbers.  We can line up the decimal points and compare starting with the greatest place value.    Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\blueE{3}$| $7$ |$.$  | $5$ | $9$ | $8$ $\blueE0$| $3$ |$.$  | $7$ | $5$ | $8$
The greatest place value with different digits is the tens place.  $37.508$ has $\blueE3$ tens.  $3.758$ has $\blueE0$ tens.  Since $\blueE37.508$ has more tens, it is greater than $\blueE03.758$.

Let's use a place value table to compare our two numbers.  We can line up the decimal points and compare starting with the greatest place value.    Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $9$ |$.$  | $3$ | $\blueD7$ | $0$ $9$ |$.$  | $3$ | $\blueD0$ | $7$

The greatest place value with different digits is the hundredths place.  $9.3\blueD70$ has $\blueD7$ hundredths. $9.3\blueD07$ has $\blueD0$ hundredths.   Since $9.3\blueD70$  has more hundredths, it is greater than $9.3\blueD07$.

Let's use a place value table to compare our two numbers.  We can line up the decimal points and compare starting with the greatest place value.    Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $1$| $6$ |$.$ | $\blueD5$ | $0$ $1$| $6$ |$.$  | $\blueD4$ | $5$

The greatest place value with different digits is the tenths place.  $16.\blueD50$ has $\blueD5$ tenths.  $16.\blueD45$ has $\blueD4$ tenths.  Since $16.\blueD50$  has more tenths, it is greater than $16.\blueD45$.

Let's use a place value table to compare our two numbers.  We can line up the decimal points and compare starting with the greatest place value.    Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $0$ |$.$  | $0$ | $\blueD8$ | $0$ $0$ |$.$  | $0$ | $\blueD0$ | $9$

The greatest place value with different digits is the hundredths place.  $0.0\blueD80$ has $\blueD8$ hundredths.  $0.0\blueD09$ has $\blueD0$ hundredths.  Since $0.0\blueD80$  has more hundredths, it is greater than $0.0\blueD09$.

Let's use a place value table to compare our two numbers.  We can line up the decimal points and compare starting with the greatest place value.    Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\blueD5$| $6$ |$.$  | $2$ | $0$ $\blueD0$| $6$ |$.$  | $5$ | $2$

The greatest place value with different digits is the tens place.  $\blueD56.20$ has $\blueD5$ tens.  $\blueD06.52$ has $\blueD0$ tens.  Since $\blueD56.20$  has more tens, it is greater than $\blueD06.52$.

Let's use a place value table to compare our two numbers.  We can line up the decimal points and compare starting with the greatest place value.    Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $2$ |$.$  | $7$ | $\blueD1$ | $2$ $2$ |$.$  | $7$ | $\blueD0$ | $6$

The greatest place value with different digits is the hundredths place.  $2.7\blueD12$ has $\blueD1$ hundredth.  $2.7\blueD06$ has $\blueD0$ hundredths.  Since $2.7\blueD12$  has more hundredths, it is greater than $2.7\blueD06$.

The greatest place value with different digits is the hundreds place.  $\blueD400.9$ has $\blueD4$ hundreds.  $\blueD049.5$ has $\blueD0$ hundreds.  Since $\blueD400.9$  has more hundreds, it is greater than $\blueD049.5$.

Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $3$| $3$ |$.$  | $\blueD3$ | $0$ | $0$ $3$| $3$ |$.$  | $\blueD0$ | $8$ | $1$

The greatest place value with different digits is the tenths place.  $33.\blueD300$ has $\blueD3$ tenths.  $33.\blueD081$ has $\blueD0$ tenths.  Since $33.\blueD300$  has more tenths, it is greater than $33.\blueD081$.

Let's use a place value table to compare our two numbers.  We can line up the decimal points and compare starting with the greatest place value.    Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $1$ |$.$  | $\blueD0$ | $1$ | $1$ $1$ |$.$  | $\blueD1$ | $0$ | $1$

The greatest place value with different digits is the tenths place.  $1.\blueD011$ has $\blueD0$ tenths. $1.\blueD101$ has $\blueD1$ tenth.   Since $1.\blueD011$  has fewer tenths, it is less than $1.\blueD101$.

Let's use a place value table to compare our two numbers.  We can line up the decimal points and compare starting with the greatest place value.    Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $7$| $1$ |$.$ | $\blueD0$ | $8$ | $0$ $7$| $1$ |$.$  | $\blueD1$ | $0$ | $6$

The greatest place value with different digits is the tenths place.  $71.\blueD08$ has $\blueD0$ tenths.  $71.\blueD106$ has $\blueD1$ tenth.  Since $71.\blueD08$ has fewer tenths, it is less than $71.\blueD106$.

The greatest place value with different digits is the ones place.  $\blueD0.85$ has $\blueD0$ ones. $\blueD5.08$ has $\blueD5$ ones.   Since $\blueD0.85$  has fewer ones, it is less than  $\blueD5.08$.

The greatest place value with different digits is the tens place.  $\blueD09.40$ has $\blueD0$ tens. $\blueD19.04$ has $\blueD1$ ten.   Since $\blueD09.40$  has fewer tens, it is less than $\blueD19.04$.

The greatest place value with different digits is the tenths place.  $60.\blueD30$ has $\blueD3$ tenths.  $60.\blueD44$ has $\blueD4$ tenths.  Since $60.\blueD30$ has fewer tenths, it is less than $60.\blueD44$.

The greatest place value with different digits is the ones place.  $\blueD2.71$ has $\blueD2$ ones. $\blueD8.00$ has $\blueD8$ ones.   Since $\blueD2.71$  has fewer ones, it is less than  $\blueD8.00$.

The digits are the same in every place value, so they are equal.
